de.esoco.storage

Class StorageManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.storage.StorageManager

  • public class StorageManager
extends java.lang.Object
    A static factory class that provides methods to create, access, and manage storage instances. This includes a thread-based storage cache for the efficient use of storages by client and server applications. To acquire a storage application code must invoke getStorage(Object). The argument to this method is a key object for which a storage definition must have been registered (see below). The returned value is a storage instance for the given key and the calling thread. Therefore separate application threads will receive different storage objects to allow the parallel use of the the same storage without explicit effort for the application.

    If an application explicitly needs a separate storage that is not shared by other method invocations in the same thread it should invoke the method newStorage(Object) which returns a new storage for a key similar to getStorage(Object). The storage instances returned by these method will not be managed by the framework, so that must be done by the application itself.

    Any storage instance that has been obtained from one of the above methods and is no longer needed must always be released to the manager by invoking the method Storage.release(). This will allow the storage manager to re-use storage instances, even if they had been created explicitly. Storages should always only be held by application code as long as they are really needed. A good rule of thumb is that the code block that acquired a storage reference should also release it.

    The storages that are available from the manager are defined through the method registerStorage(StorageDefinition, Object...) by registering a storage definition with a corresponding key object. The key can be an arbitrary object and it's meaning is completely application dependent. An application could use, for example, the classes of the objects stored as the keys to associated storage definitions. Or it may use specific constants like strings or enums to identify different storage areas. An application may also (or alternatively) register a default storage definition through the method setDefaultStorage(StorageDefinition) which will then be used for all storage keys that have no been associated with a specific storage definition.

      • convertToSqlConstraint

        public static java.lang.String convertToSqlConstraint(java.lang.String sConstraint)
        Converts a string constraint to the corresponding SQL constraint (for a SQL LIKE statement) by replacing '*' with '%' and '_' with '?'.
        Parameters:
        sConstraint - The original constraint string
        Returns:
        The converted string

      • getMapping

        public static <T> StorageMapping<T,?,?> getMapping(java.lang.Class<T> rType)
        Returns the storage mapping for a certain datatype class. If no type has been registered for the type a new instance of ClassMapping will be returned.
        Parameters:
        rType - The class to return the mapping for mapping
        Returns:
        The storage mapping for the given type

      • getMappingFactory

        public static <T> StorageManager.MappingFactory<T> getMappingFactory(java.lang.Class<T> rBaseClass)
        Returns the storage mapping factory for a certain base class.
        Parameters:
        rBaseClass - The base class to register the factory for
        Returns:
        The mapping factory or NULL if none has been registered yet
        See Also:
        registerMappingFactory(Class, MappingFactory)

      • getStorage

        public static Storage getStorage(java.lang.Object rKey)
                          throws StorageException
        Returns a storage instance from a storage definition that has been registered for a certain key. If no specific storage definition can be found an instance of the default storage will be returned (if the default storage definition has been set).

        This method should normally be preferred over the direct creation of storages with the method newStorage(Object) because it performs a thread-based caching of storages and thus provides a way to access a storage over multiple stack levels without the requirement to pass storages by parameter. After user the storage should be released as soon as possible by invoking the method releaseStorage(Storage).

        See the class documentation for more information about the storage management.

        Parameters:
        rKey - The key to return a storage instance for
        Returns:
        A storage instance from the storage definition associated with the given key
        Throws:
        StorageException - If neither a specific nor a default storage definition is available for the given key or if creating the storage fails

      • getStorageDefinition

        public static StorageDefinition getStorageDefinition(java.lang.Object rKey)
        Returns the storage definition for a certain key. Returns the storage definition for a certain key that has been registered with the method registerStorage(StorageDefinition, Object...). If no such definition can be found and a default storage definition has been set with the method setDefaultStorage(StorageDefinition) the default will be returned.

        See the class documentation for more information about the storage management.

        Parameters:
        rKey - The storage key
        Returns:
        Either the matching storage definition, the default definition, or NULL if none of these has been set

      • isPersistent

        public static boolean isPersistent(java.lang.Object rObject)
        Checks whether a certain object is already persistent in a storage. This will be true if the object has been stored in or retrieved from a storage previously.
        Parameters:
        rObject - The object to check for persistence
        Returns:
        TRUE if the object is already persistent in a storage

      • newStorage

        public static Storage newStorage(java.lang.Object rKey)
                          throws StorageException
        Returns a new storage instance from a storage definition that has been registered for a certain key. If no specific storage definition can be found an instance of the default storage will be returned (if the default definition has been set).

        This method always returns a newly created storage instance. Therefore applications should in general prefer to call getStorage(Object) instead to allow the implementation to cache storage instance. Only if a new instance is explicitly needed (e.g. to perform storage operations separately from the default storage instance) this method should be used. The management of the returned storage instance is completely up to the calling code. When the returned storage is no longer needed it must be released by invoking the method releaseStorage(Storage).

        See the class documentation for more information about the storage management.

        Parameters:
        rKey - The key to return a storage instance for
        Returns:
        A new storage instance from the storage definition associated with the given key
        Throws:
        StorageException - If neither a specific nor a default storage definition is available

      • registerMappingFactory

        public static <T> void registerMappingFactory(java.lang.Class<T> rBaseClass,
                                              StorageManager.MappingFactory<T> rFactory)
        Registers a storage mapping factory for a certain base class. This factory will then be used to create storage mappings for the given class and all it's subclasses.
        Parameters:
        rBaseClass - The base class to register the factory for
        rFactory - The factor to register

      • registerStorage

        public static void registerStorage(StorageDefinition rDefinition,
                                   java.lang.Object... rKeys)
        Registers a storage type by associating it's definition with certain keys for the lookup of storages. If a storage is queried through either of the getStorage(Object) or newStorage(Object) methods the storage definition associated with the given keys will be used to create a new storage if necessary. If no storage definition has been associated with a certain key the definition that has been set by means of the method setDefaultStorage(StorageDefinition) will be used.

        See the class documentation for more information about the storage management.

        Parameters:
        rDefinition - The storage definition instance to register
        rKeys - The keys to associate the definition with (must not be empty)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If either argument is NULL or if rKeys is empty

      • setDefaultStorage

        public static void setDefaultStorage(StorageDefinition rDefinition)
        Sets the definition for the default storage. This storage definition will be used by the method getStorage(Object) for all keys for which no specific storage definition has been registered through the method registerStorage(StorageDefinition, Object...).

        See the class documentation for more information about the storage management.

        Parameters:
        rDefinition - The new default storage definition

      • setStorageMetaData

        public static <T> void setStorageMetaData(org.obrel.core.RelationType<T> rType,
                                          T rValue)
        Sets the storage meta data.
        Parameters:
        rType - The new storage meta data
        rValue - The new storage meta data

      • shutdown

        public static void shutdown()
        Performs a shutdown of the storage manager and frees all allocated resources.
